Lecture: Derivatives as Limits — The Algebraic Definition

Objective

To introduce the formal definition of the derivative using limits, and apply it to compute derivatives of well-known functions. This builds on the intuition of average and instantaneous rate of change.

Motivation Review: From Average to Instantaneous

Recall from our last lecture:

  • The average rate of change between two points on a function:

    Average Rate=f(x+h)−f(x)h\text{Average Rate} = \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h} Average Rate=hf(x+h)−f(x)​

  • As h→0h \to 0h→0, we approach the instantaneous rate of change, or the derivative:

    f′(x)=lim⁡h→0f(x+h)−f(x)hf'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h} f′(x)=h→0lim​hf(x+h)−f(x)​

This is called the difference quotient. It's the heart of differential calculus.

Algebraic Definition of the Derivative

Let f(x)f(x)f(x) be a function. The derivative of fff at a point xxx is:

f′(x)=lim⁡h→0f(x+h)−f(x)hf'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h} f′(x)=h→0lim​hf(x+h)−f(x)​

If this limit exists, fff is said to be differentiable at xxx.

This limit represents the slope of the tangent line to the graph of fff at xxx.

Step-by-Step Example: f(x)=x2f(x) = x^2f(x)=x2

Let us compute f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) using the limit definition:

f′(x)=lim⁡h→0(x+h)2−x2hf'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{(x + h)^2 - x^2}{h} f′(x)=h→0lim​h(x+h)2−x2​

Expand:

=lim⁡h→0x2+2xh+h2−x2h=lim⁡h→02xh+h2h= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{x^2 + 2xh + h^2 - x^2}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{2xh + h^2}{h} =h→0lim​hx2+2xh+h2−x2​=h→0lim​h2xh+h2​

=lim⁡h→0(2x+h)=2x= \lim_{h \to 0} (2x + h) = 2x =h→0lim​(2x+h)=2x

So, f′(x)=2xf'(x) = 2xf′(x)=2x.

Another Example: f(x)=1xf(x) = \frac{1}{x}f(x)=x1​

f′(x)=lim⁡h→01x+h−1xhf'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{1}{x + h} - \frac{1}{x}}{h} f′(x)=h→0lim​hx+h1​−x1​​

Use common denominator:

=lim⁡h→0x−(x+h)x(x+h)h=lim⁡h→0−hhx(x+h)= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{x - (x + h)}{x(x + h)}}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{-h}{hx(x + h)} =h→0lim​hx(x+h)x−(x+h)​​=h→0lim​hx(x+h)−h​

Cancel hhh:

=lim⁡h→0−1x(x+h)=−1x2= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{-1}{x(x + h)} = -\frac{1}{x^2} =h→0lim​x(x+h)−1​=−x21​

So, f′(x)=−1x2f'(x) = -\frac{1}{x^2}f′(x)=−x21​

Additional Examples

1. f(x)=xf(x) = \sqrt{x}f(x)=x​

f′(x)=lim⁡h→0x+h−xhf'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sqrt{x + h} - \sqrt{x}}{h} f′(x)=h→0lim​hx+h​−x​​

Multiply by the conjugate:

=lim⁡h→0x+h−xh(x+h+x)=lim⁡h→01x+h+x=12x= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{x + h - x}{h(\sqrt{x + h} + \sqrt{x})} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{1}{\sqrt{x + h} + \sqrt{x}} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}} =h→0lim​h(x+h​+x​)x+h−x​=h→0lim​x+h​+x​1​=2x​1​

2. f(x)=∣x∣f(x) = |x|f(x)=∣x∣

f′(x)=lim⁡h→0∣x+h∣−∣x∣hf'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{|x + h| - |x|}{h} f′(x)=h→0lim​h∣x+h∣−∣x∣​

at x=0x = 0x=0, we have:

lim⁡h→0∣0+h∣−∣0∣h=lim⁡h→0∣h∣h\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{|0 + h| - |0|}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{|h|}{h} h→0lim​h∣0+h∣−∣0∣​=h→0lim​h∣h∣​

Looking at the left and right limits, we have:

lim⁡h→0−∣h∣h=−1andlim⁡h→0+∣h∣h=1\lim_{h \to 0^-} \frac{|h|}{h} = -1 \quad \text{and} \quad \lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{|h|}{h} = 1 h→0−lim​h∣h∣​=−1andh→0+lim​h∣h∣​=1

Since the left and right limits are not equal, the limit does not exist.

This limit does not exist at x=0x = 0x=0. So f(x)=∣x∣f(x) = |x|f(x)=∣x∣ is not differentiable at x=0x = 0x=0.

Famous Derivatives

Function Derivative
f(x)=xnf(x) = x^nf(x)=xn f′(x)=nxn−1f'(x) = nx^{n-1}f′(x)=nxn−1
f(x)=sin⁡(x)f(x) = \sin(x)f(x)=sin(x) f′(x)=cos⁡(x)f'(x) = \cos(x)f′(x)=cos(x)
f(x)=cos⁡(x)f(x) = \cos(x)f(x)=cos(x) f′(x)=−sin⁡(x)f'(x) = -\sin(x)f′(x)=−sin(x)
f(x)=exf(x) = e^xf(x)=ex f′(x)=exf'(x) = e^xf′(x)=ex
f(x)=ln⁡(x)f(x) = \ln(x)f(x)=ln(x) f′(x)=1xf'(x) = \frac{1}{x}f′(x)=x1​

Exercises

1. Find derivatives

Using the limit definition, find the derivative of the following functions:

  • (a) f(x)=x3f(x) = x^3f(x)=x3

  • (b) f(x)=xf(x) = \sqrt{x}f(x)=x​

  • (c) f(x)=2x+5f(x) = 2x + 5f(x)=2x+5

  • (d) f(x)=3x4f(x) = 3x^4f(x)=3x4

  • (e) f(x)=x−2f(x) = x^{-2}f(x)=x−2

  • (f) f(x)=5f(x) = 5f(x)=5

2. Prove from the limit definition:

  • (a) f(x)=1x⇒f′(x)=−1x2f(x) = \frac{1}{x} \Rightarrow f'(x) = -\frac{1}{x^2}f(x)=x1​⇒f′(x)=−x21​
  • (b) f(x)=x2+3x⇒f′(x)=2x+3f(x) = x^2 + 3x \Rightarrow f'(x) = 2x + 3f(x)=x2+3x⇒f′(x)=2x+3

3. Find f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) using the limit definition.

  • (a) f(x)=1x2+1f(x) = \frac{1}{x^2 + 1}f(x)=x2+11​
  • (b) f(x)=1xf(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}f(x)=x​1​

4. logarithmic function

Derive the formula for f(x)=ln⁡(x)f(x) = \ln(x)f(x)=ln(x) from the limit definition:

f′(x)=lim⁡h→0ln⁡(x+h)−ln⁡(x)hf'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\ln(x + h) - \ln(x)}{h} f′(x)=h→0lim​hln(x+h)−ln(x)​

Use the identity: ln⁡(x+h)−ln⁡(x)=ln⁡(1+hx)\ln(x + h) - \ln(x) = \ln\left(1 + \frac{h}{x}\right)ln(x+h)−ln(x)=ln(1+xh​), and the definition of eee.

5. absolute value function

Let f(x)=∣x−1∣f(x) = |x - 1|f(x)=∣x−1∣. Determine where fff is not differentiable and explain why using the limit definition.

Extra Advanced Exercises:

1. Piecewise Function Differentiability

Let:

f(x)={x2+2x,x<1ax+b,x≥1f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2 + 2x, & x < 1 \\ ax + b, & x \geq 1 \end{cases} f(x)={x2+2x,ax+b,​x<1x≥1​

Find values of aaa and bbb such that:

  • (a) fff is continuous at x=1x = 1x=1
  • (b) fff is differentiable at x=1x = 1x=1

2. Challenge with Radical and Rational Function

Use the limit definition to find f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) for:

f(x)=xx+1f(x) = \frac{x}{\sqrt{x + 1}} f(x)=x+1​x​

3. Limit Form Involving Trigonometry

Use the identity:

lim⁡h→0sin⁡(h)h=1\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(h)}{h} = 1 h→0lim​hsin(h)​=1

to derive:

ddx(sin⁡(x))=cos⁡(x)\frac{d}{dx}(\sin(x)) = \cos(x) dxd​(sin(x))=cos(x)

4. Absolute and Rational Hybrid

Let:

f(x)=∣x∣xf(x) = \frac{|x|}{x} f(x)=x∣x∣​

  • (a) Use the limit definition to determine where f(x)f(x)f(x) is differentiable.
  • (b) Graph it and explain why the derivative does or does not exist at certain points.

5. Pointwise Derivative of a Nowhere-Differentiable Function

Read about the Weierstrass function:

f(x)=∑n=0∞ancos⁡(bnπx)with 0<a<1, b odd, ab>1+3π2f(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a^n \cos(b^n \pi x) \quad \text{with } 0 < a < 1, \ b \text{ odd, } ab > 1 + \frac{3\pi}{2} f(x)=n=0∑∞​ancos(bnπx)with 0<a<1, b odd, ab>1+23π​

  • (a) Explain why this function is continuous everywhere
  • (b) Investigate why it is not differentiable anywhere
  • (c) Attempt a limit-based justification (conceptual only)

Wrap-Up

  • Derivatives measure instantaneous change, defined using limits
  • The limit definition is foundational, even if we later use rules to shortcut the process
  • Not all functions are differentiable everywhere (e.g., piecewise, absolute value, radicals at zero)
